Better than GNOME boxes, for it has many more features and adjustments that your VM could probably do with, and I noticed that it is a lot more stable, even though Boxes is based on this.
Older reviews seem to say it has an outdated GUI, but that has been improved and will work with any GTK theme you throw at it.

Because it provides detailed configuration possibilities it might be a little complicated to start with. But it gives you a lot of options. Highly recommended.

Virtual Machine Manager takes a little time to get used to, but learning it is really worth its while. It's fast, highly configurable and provides a reliable host environment for operating systems like Windows 7, for which high-quality guest additions (drivers and such) are available through the SPICE project.

I like virt-manager because it allows me to interface with kvm/qemu; which is the native way of virtualizing guests in GNU & Linux. 

There isn't anything faster or better in this realm!
Powerful with QEMU/KVM

VM manager provides the easiest and most flexible way for advanced users to manage virtual machines. Don't, however, expect to be able to set it up properly if you aren't already good with Linux. See, VM manager is a frontend to libvirt, which is a frontend to a number of hypervisors. You will need to set up a hypervisor (QEMU, QEMU/KVM, LXD, or Xen), libvirt, AND VM manager before you can create virtual machines. This is by design and provides flexibility.

Use GNOME Boxes if you aren't able to set this up; it uses the same underlying technology but has an easier interface.
summary: The absolute best, but only for the tech-savvy

description: i am new to use ubuntu
summary: my laptop inside not working (libvirt-bin error)

description: ssh connections, excellent vmm

Virtual Machine Manager is a simple GUI to libvirt and can manage a number of hypervisors - QEMU/kvm, Xen, lxd, etc. It even supports remote access so one can manage VMs on multiple hosts.
The GUI is sort of intuitive, if you know what you are doing. Documentation, however, is scarce.
Being a front-end to libvirt, virt-manager lacks behind the development and does not support all the bells and whistles that come with libvirt. Some of the pull-down-menus are incomplete, for example the CPU model does not offer the option "host-passthrough" which still needs to be entered manually.

Luckily a xml editor was added, which is often required to fix or fine-tune the configuration.

virt-manager supports the creation of storage pools, but the defaults are - like with libvirt itself - not very helpful. Why would anyone want to place virtual machine storage under /var ?

One can create other storage pools and even LVM is supported. But it's not as straightforward as one might hope.

A big minus is the lack of any backup facility. Backing up the VM storage can be accomplished with regular Linux tools inside the host OS. But what about the VM configurations?

They are "stored" under /etc/libvirt/qemu (for QEMU/kvm) and looking at the files shows this warning at the beginning:
"WARNING: THIS IS AN AUTO-GENERATED FILE."

The only way I found to backup (and restore) the configuration is to copy the XML configuration from the virt-manager Virtual Machine Details XML Overview window to a file and save it.

Another thing is NOT to rely on the virt-manager defaults. For example, it will automatically enable memballoon although many OSes won't support it.

The list goes on. However, the biggest issue is the lack of decent documentation. Many users have written tutorials that explain how to get a job done (myself included), but that does not replace the documentation only the developers can provide.

Given the limited features and capabilities, Virtual Machine Manager may be suitable for private/home use or small networks with a limited number of hosts and VMs.
summary: Helps get the job done, but there is a lot to improve
